form.steps:
1. Fasten an elastic band high up (e.g., on a cable machine or a sturdy anchor point). 
2. Grip the band with both hands, step away from the anchor point, and stand sideways to it with your feet shoulder-width apart. 
3. With almost straight arms, make a sweeping, chopping-like movement diagonally downward, pulling the band across your body towards your opposite hip. 
4. Return to the starting position in a controlled manner, resisting the pull of the band.

form.Core: Engage your core throughout the exercise to stabilize your body and control the movement.
form.Arms: Keep your arms almost straight but not locked.
form.Shoulders: Initiate the movement from your core, not just your shoulders.
form.Back: Maintain a straight back and avoid hunching over during the exercise.

commonMistakes.Using only arms: Using only your arms to pull the band instead of engaging your core.
commonMistakes.Rotating your hips: Rotating your hips and torso too much, which reduces the engagement of the obliques.
commonMistakes.Rushing the movement: Performing the exercise too quickly, which compromises form and reduces muscle activation.

comments.Muscle activation: Banded wood chops from high to low are a good exercise for your oblique abdominal muscles, as it combines its rotating and flexing actions on the torso.
comments.Variations: You can also perform this exercise from low to high, starting the movement from a low position and pulling the band diagonally upwards.

alternativesAndVariations.Cable Wood Chop: Similar to the banded version but uses a cable machine instead of a resistance band.
alternativesAndVariations.Medicine Ball Wood Chop: A more dynamic variation that uses a medicine ball instead of a band, adding a throwing and catching element to the exercise.
alternativesAndVariations.Russian Twist: A bodyweight exercise that targets the obliques by rotating the torso from side to side while holding a weight or medicine ball.
alternativesAndVariations.Side Plank Oblique Crunch: A challenging exercise that combines a side plank with an oblique crunch, targeting both the obliques and the core stabilizers.

high-to-low-wood-chop-with-band.tempo: 2011 (2 seconds lowering, 0 seconds pause at the bottom, 1 second lifting, 1 second pause at the top)
